info.description: A one-sample t-test is a statistical test used to determine whether the mean of a sample significantly differs from a known or hypothesized population mean. It is typically used when we have a single sample and want to compare its mean to a specific value.

info.description: The Mann-Whitney test, also known as the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, is a nonparametric statistical test used to determine whether there is a significant difference between the distributions of two independent samples. It is often used when the data does not meet the assumptions of parametric tests like the t-test.

info.description: The Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test for an normal distribution is a statistical test used to determine if a sample of data follows an normal distribution. It compares the empirical cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the sample data with the theoretical CDF of the normal distribution.

info.description: The Lilliefors test, also known as the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for normality, is a statistical test used to determine whether a sample comes from a normal distribution. It is an extension of the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, which is used to test the goodness-of-fit of any continuous distribution.

info.description: The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test used to determine if a given sample of data comes from a normally distributed population. It is a widely-used test for normality in statistical analysis. The Shapiro-Wilk test is particularly useful when the sample size is small (typically less than 50) and when the assumption of normality is crucial for subsequent statistical analysis, such as parametric tests like t-tests or ANOVA.

info.description: The chi-square test in scipy is a statistical test used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables. It is based on the chi-square statistic, which measures the difference between the observed and expected frequencies of each category
